thread.title: EastEnders fans unimpressed after spotting ANOTHER production gaffe: "A hand-held rat? Really?"
thread.title_full: EastEnders fans unimpressed after spotting ANOTHER production gaffe: "A hand-held rat? Really?"

author: mirror
title: EastEnders fans unimpressed after spotting ANOTHER production gaffe: "A hand-held rat? Really?"
text:
Get soaps   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
It has suffered a string of production bloopers in recent weeks - and that shows no sign of going away for EastEnders fans, as last night's episode proved. 
Viewers of the BBC1 soap were left rolling their eyes after a crew-member could be seen manipulating a hot with a rogue rodent on Tuesday's broadcast. 
As Honey, Donna and Carmel discussed Albert Square being rat-infested, fans spotted a crew-member's hand holding on to the animal’s tail in the Minute Mart. The animal-handler was clearly in sight, as viewers were keen to point-out (Photo: BBC) 
Naturally, they took to social media to vent their spleen, where they were rather unforgiving about the gaffe. 
One posted: "Oh dear! The rat had a hand getting out of the Mini Mart last night", while another wrote: "Fantastic work by EastEnders tonight, they forgot to edit out the hand holding the rat.” 
A third chimed in: “What is up with these blunders you keep having? A hand-held rat - really?". Fans took tom social media to highlight the show's latest error (Photo: BBC) As Honey, Donna and Carmel discussed Albert Square being rat-infested, fans spotted it (Photo: BBC) 
The error is just the latest in a long line of mistakes by BBC staff. 
Last week, viewers were left puzzled when Mick Carter celebrated his 40th birthday on the wrong date. 
Then, disgruntled fans lodged complaints with Ofcom after two characters swore before the watershed. Read More Awkwardly, Mick Carter celebrated his birthday on the wrong date (Photo: BBC) (Photo: BBC) 
Sharon Mitchell and Michelle Fowler turned the air blue on Thursday night’s episode, sparking more than 80 complaints to the broadcasting watchdog. 
Shocked viewers – many watching with children – voiced their anger after hearing words including “b
